rows.text_1:
Today's lesson is about creating structure for our children.

Rules and routines help children understand what is expected from them, be responsible, and stay safe. 

Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them TOGETHER.  

Creating daily routines (around for example meals, school and bedtime) will help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does anybody else find getting their children ready for school or bed stressful?

Guess what? Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

rows.text_1: Let’s look at an example together. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name is spending too much time watching TV before her homework is finished. @data.characters.f1_mother.name helps him create a family rule about this:

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f1_mother.name: “It is important that you get your homework done so you can do well in school. Let’s make a rule about watching TV so that you have enough time for homework, too.”
@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Okay, Mum.”

@data.characters.f1_mother.name: “What do you think would be a fair rule?”
@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Hmmm…well, maybe I can watch TV as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?”

@data.characters.f1_mother.name: “I like that idea, but let’s limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?”
@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Fine.”

@data.characters.f1_mother.name: “Thank you for doing your homework before watching TV, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Last night you mentioned that your math tests have become easier for you! I am proud of you! We can increase your time to an hour each day… as long as you still do your homework first!”
@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Thank you, Mum!”

rows.text_1: Let’s look at another family. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your blocks, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.”

 @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name: “Okay!”

*5 minutes later*

 @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. First, let’s get you nice and clean with a bath.”
@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.”

@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name! Now let’s brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!”

@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?”

 @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name: “Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?”

@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name: “ “The end….” I’m glad you chose that story for us to read, it’s one of my favourites! Goodnight, my baby girl. I love you very much.”

 @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name: “Goodnight, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name.”

rows.text_1: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home:
rows.section_1_text: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them. One rule at a time is easiest.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.
rows.section_2_text:
Consider your child’s age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time – you can add another one later.
rows.section_2_extra_text: Make rules and routines realistic for what your child can actually do and specific so there is no misunderstanding. Don’t say “ “clean up” but “pick up all of your blocks”.
rows.section_3_text:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.
rows.section_3_extra_text: Activities become easier when children learn and get used to a routine.

rows.text_1:
Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
Bedtime was always a struggle in our house. My children wanted to keep watching TV and I would always end up shouting at them: “Go to bed now! You know you have to be ready for school early in the morning!”. Some days I was just too tired, and I would let them watch more TV. 

When we learned in @global.app_name about rules, I learned that it is important to be consistent. I discussed with my children why watching TV till late is a problem, and we came up with a rule together to switch off the TV at 8 and be ready for bed by 8.30. Now everyone knows what is expected of them, and we can end the day peacefully.
rows.quiz_1_question: Can you set one routine and one rule with your child?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! I hope it makes your home feel easier to manage for everyone.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's okay. Setting rules is hard and including children can feel uncomfortable, especially if you’re not used to it. Keep trying until you find a way that works for you and your children. I promise, it will be worth it!
